initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories:
A British journalist stationed in Japan has been detained in China, the UK embassy says.

The Chinese foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 29-year-old was not on official assignment when he was held on 5 June in the city of Shanghai.

Journalist Smith had been in the process of transitioning to a new media organization in Japan, according to a statement from the UK embassy.

But instead of going back to the UK, he traveled to China for personal reasons, a UK embassy spokesperson said in a statement.

According to Chinese media, he was meeting with sources for a story he was working on.

The journalist's mother, Alice Smith, confirmed to BBC that he was in China for work purposes.

"Please treat him with respect and ensure his safety," Alice Smith said when asked about her message to the Chinese government.

Journalist Smith began his career as a freelancer in 2015 and had covered stories in various countries. He was most recently working as a foreign correspondent in Japan.

He did not seek approval from his employer for the trip to China and the media company did not authorize his travel. There is no evidence he had any intention of breaking the law in China.

The UK embassy in Beijing was informed by the Chinese authorities on 6 June that Journalist Smith had been detained for allegedly violating press regulations.

He is currently being held at a detention center until further notice.

"The embassy has been in contact with his family and we are providing all necessary assistance to the journalist in China," the UK embassy said in a statement on Tuesday.

Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab told the press that the UK government is "monitoring the situation closely".

At a media briefing, Mr. Raab said they are in communication with Chinese authorities regarding the case.

China is currently holding several other foreign journalists on various charges. The international community has raised concerns over press freedom in the country.

An American photographer based in India has been detained in Pakistan, the US embassy states.

The Pakistani government claims that the charges are not politically motivated, but rather stem from a local crime.

The 32-year-old was not on assignment when he was arrested on July 15 in the city of Lahore.

Photographer Brown had recently left his job to pursue freelance opportunities in India, as per a statement from the US embassy.

Instead of returning to the US, he decided to visit Pakistan for personal reasons, a US embassy representative mentioned in a press release.

Reports from Pakistani media suggest that he was gathering material for a photo essay he was developing.

The photographer's father, John Brown, confirmed to local news outlets that his son was in Pakistan for professional purposes.

"Please treat him with dignity and ensure his well-being," John Brown stated when asked about his message to Pakistani authorities.

Photographer Brown began his career as a photojournalist in 2013 and had captured images in several countries. He was most recently photographing cultural events in India.

There was no approval sought from his former employer for the trip to Pakistan and his company did not authorize his travel. There is no indication that he intended to violate any laws in Pakistan.

The US embassy in Islamabad was notified by Pakistani officials on July 16 that Photographer Brown had been detained for alleged violations of media regulations.

He is currently being held at a detention facility until further notice.

"The embassy is in contact with his family and is offering all necessary support to the photographer in Pakistan," the US embassy stated in a release on Wednesday.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo told the media that the US government is "closely monitoring the situation".

During a press conference, Mr. Pompeo mentioned that they are liaising with Pakistani authorities regarding the incident.

Pakistan currently has several other foreign journalists in custody on various charges. The global community has expressed concerns about press freedom in the region.

A Canadian filmmaker based in Thailand has been detained in Indonesia, the Canadian embassy confirms.

The Indonesian government claims that the charges are related to visa violations, not political reasons.

The 29-year-old filmmaker was exploring the country when he was arrested on August 20 in the city of Jakarta.

Filmmaker White had recently completed a documentary project in Thailand and was traveling to Indonesia for leisure, according to a statement from the Canadian embassy.

Instead of returning to Canada, he decided to extend his stay in Southeast Asia and visit Indonesia for personal reasons, a Canadian embassy representative mentioned in a press release.

Local media reports suggest that he was working on a new film project exploring Indonesian culture and traditions.

The filmmaker's mother, Mary White, confirmed to local news outlets that her son was in Indonesia for creative purposes.

"Please ensure his safety and well-being during his time in detention," Mary White stated when asked about her message to Indonesian authorities.

Filmmaker White started his career in the film industry in 2015 and had produced documentaries in multiple countries. He was most recently working on a project focusing on environmental issues in Southeast Asia.

There were no travel restrictions in place from his previous projects that would have prevented his trip to Indonesia. There is no evidence to suggest that he intended to break any Indonesian laws.

The Canadian embassy in Jakarta was informed by Indonesian officials on August 21 that Filmmaker White had been detained for visa-related violations.

He is currently being held at an immigration detention center pending further proceedings.

"The embassy is in constant communication with his family and is providing necessary assistance to the filmmaker in Indonesia," the Canadian embassy stated in a release on Thursday.

Foreign Minister François-Philippe Champagne mentioned that the Canadian government is "closely following the situation".

During a diplomatic meeting, Mr. Champagne noted that they are working with Indonesian authorities to address the issue.

Indonesia currently has a few other foreign filmmakers in custody on similar charges. The international community is expressing concerns about the treatment of creatives in the region.
